video.title: Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text: Today is the last day SharkRobot.com is selling their limited run of exclusive ZP shirts, hoodies and hats.
So you&#39;d better snap them up. Unless you not watching this the day it comes out, in which case...
Hey, remember that great ZP merch you could have brought. Maybe missing out on that was when your life
started going downhill.

Somewhere along the line the reaction to triple-A
hype drifted from &quot;Ooh I&#39;m excited for this&quot;

to &quot;Ooh it&#39;s not immediately obvious how they&#39;re
going to fuck this one up.&quot; Such was the case

with Jedi: Fallen Order. EA brings out a new
Star Wars game and after Battlefront 2 I cringe

like an abused dog expecting another newspaper
across the snout &#39;cos I expect them to charge

micropayments for Yoda&#39;s every last misarranged
sentence. But no, for once triple-A is using

its powers for good - by powers I mean enormous
wealth but, hey, it&#39;s never made a difference

to Batman - they made a good old-fashioned
single player action adventure cobbled together

from good ideas cribbed from other single
player action adventures that people seem

to like and the result is a perfectly solid
if somewhat unoriginal game that people seem

to like that they barely even tried to wring
out for maximum cash. Although I&#39;m sure the

only reason EA were willing to take the risk
is because it&#39;s Star Wars. It could never&#39;ve

turned a profit otherwise, since publishers
continue to insist it&#39;s standard practise

that triple-A games be developed on solid
gold desks with computers liquid cooled by
the semen of prizewinning stallions.

The story of Jedi: Fallen Orlen concerns Cal
Kestis, hitherto unknown non-Luke Skywalker

human Jedi type fellow and radioactive ginge.
Not to be confused with Kyle Katarn, non-Luke

Skywalker human Jedi type fellow from the
Dark Forces games amongst others. Thus Disney&#39;s

sinister scheme is laid bare - scrap the Star
Wars expanded universe, then replace it with

something exactly like it but just distinct
enough that they can claim ownership. Thus

successfully achieving what the evil empire
never could. If only Palpatine had thought

to buy out the Jedi&#39;s parent companies instead
of purging them. Anyway, Cal is forced to

come out of hiding and embark upon an odyssey
across the galaxy to find an archive of potential

future Jedis that might spell the rebirth
of the Jedi Order. Although since this game

takes place between episodes three and four,
we know right up front that things aren&#39;t

going to work out like that. Since Episode
4 was called A New Hope, not Another Hope

To Add To The Pile. Cal, who seems to have
a problem with his jaw that makes it constantly

jut forwards like he&#39;s trying to bite his
own nose off, bears a number of suspicious

parallels with other Star Wars protagonists
- humble starting point, secret Force powers,

has a robot pal who talks like Stephen Hawking
learning to whistle...

But Luke Skywalker was always a direct copy
paste of the standard heroic monomyth, so

when I imply that Cal is cribbing him off,
what I mean is that all the characters and

story arcs in this game are tired and obvious
tropes. The haunted mentor, the roguish captain

with a heart of gold, we&#39;ve even got our very
own custom Darth Vader. A lady Vader, no less,

Darth Lader, who has their very own identity
reveal twist that for the record I called

about two hours beforehand. Nothing wrong
with falling back on hero with a thousand

faces as long as we have some decent swordfights,
Yahtzee. If you say so, but sometimes it feels

like Fallen Hors d&#39;oeuvre is trying to hit
the checkpoints on the story arcs without

putting in the legwork, if you see what I
mean. Like when our mentor sits us down mid-fast

travel for some character building and goes
&quot;I know you don&#39;t trust me anymore,&quot; and I&#39;m

like, &quot;I don&#39;t? News to me, I&#39;ve just been
going up and down ziplines for the last two

hours.&quot; And then there&#39;s the bit on the fourth
planet where we&#39;re literally outside the boss

fight and the game slams the door in our face
and says &quot;Where d&#39;ya think you&#39;re going? You

have to be at your lowest emotional point
before the final act! Kapow! You are now sad.

Go to this whole other fucking planet for
a vision quest and don&#39;t come back until you&#39;ve
had an epiphany, asshole.&quot;

As for gameplay, it has been seduced by the
dark side of the souls. So you know the drill.

Exploration, difficult combat, enemies respawn
when you use checkpoints. And they don&#39;t even

try to explain why that happens in context.
I guess while we&#39;re napping the Empire just

dispatches more soldiers to stand exactly
where the previous ones were to try and figure

out what went wrong, with the faultless logic
of a true middle manager. I went for the second

highest of the four difficulty settings to
find the balance between a Dark Soulsy level

of challenge and actually getting through
the fucking thing over the weekend, and can

report that it felt perfectly satisfactory.
Fighting some of the melee enemies can be

frustrating when they keep blocking your attacks
not because of the physics of the situation

but because &quot;nuh-uh, everything-proof-shield&quot;
but two realisations eventually made the combat

click - first, that the focus is on blocking
and parrying rather than dodging, and secondly,

you&#39;re a fucking space wizard, use space magic
to cheat. Force Push does a lot to counteract

everything-proof-shields and if you get bored
of parrying standard enemies a force pull

and a stab will one-shot most of them. Probably
not a strictly light side of the force sort

of technique, making someone helpless and
flash-searing their pancreas, but fuck it,
the game doesn&#39;t judge.

In fact, besides a couple of moments where
Cal &quot;I Play Kerplunk With Human Torsos&quot; Kestis

has the balls to call out other people for
doing dark-sidey things, the whole light side

dark side thing isn&#39;t really present as a
theme. Cal doesn&#39;t come across as either noble

OR tempted by evil. He mostly comes across
like a cardboard box with an underbite. I

struggle to think of any theme the plot could
be said to have. I wonder if this is related

to the increasing triple-A aversion to taking
political stances for maximum broad appeal,

we&#39;d hate to alienate all the potential buyers
who think nailing helpless people to noticeboards

is the tops. Anyway, the gameplay also features
climbing traversal in the Prince of Uncharted

Persia zone which is executed well enough
I can&#39;t even nitpick, whereas the 3D map and

exploration reminds me pleasantly of Metroid
Prime. It&#39;s got something Dark Souls has always

needed, a device that clearly indicates what
is and is not an exit from the room, so I

don&#39;t miss out on entire zones because I forgot
to check behind a decorative hedge. You get

abilities that open new areas as you go along
Metroidvania style, but it&#39;s the bad Metroidvania

thing where the different zones don&#39;t interconnect
so you rarely have a chance to pass through

old areas picking up newly accessible items
on your way to the next point in the critical
path.

You have to go out of your way to collect
optional items, and then 90% of them turn

out to just be fucking cosmetics. For your
light sabre. Oh, praise the bloated neck folds

of George Lucas, I can replace the bit on
my light sabre that looks like a harmonica

with another bit that looks like a duck, never
mind that in general gameplay it&#39;s about three

pixels across and mostly concealed by Cal&#39;s
fat sweaty mitts. This is my motivation to

engage with the optional exploring, is it,
Jedi Fallen Order? What&#39;s wrong with a nice

concept art gallery? Or unlockable heart-patterned
boxer shorts costume? So that covers my main

gripes, but in my trademark backhanded freewheeling
infuriatingly hard to pin down editorial style,

I&#39;m now going to recommend Jedi Border Collie.
It hasn&#39;t an original bone in its body, but

it has mashed together several ideas from
prior classics in a technically original combination

and produced the expected result of a perfectly
fine game. Looks nice, plays nice, story like

stale loaf of wonder bread on a silver platter,
but that&#39;s about as good as triple-A can manage

these days. Good storytelling after all requires
a soul. Not the rotting corpse of a canary
in a tiny cage made of share certificates.
